Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Predicting Nanoparticle Targeted Delivery Efficacy in Vascular Environment through Multiscale Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0955214
Liu

Nanoparticulate systems have been widely used in diagnostic imaging and targeted therapeutic applications in recent years. One of the major challenges in nanomedicine is to improve particle selectivity and adhesion efficiency under complex vascular flow conditions. To deliver nanomedicine directly to the desired diseased tissue while minimizing deposition/uptake by healthy tissues along the pathway, the design of nanoparticle need to be considered together with the diseased region's physical parameters (e.g. vascular diameter, blood flow rate, surface area, etc). The goal of the proposed career development strategy is to uncover the adhesion dynamics of nanoparticles and predict targeted delivery efficacy under complex vascular environment through a multiscale modeling approach. In pursue of this goal, a 3D multiscale model of nanoparticle transport, dispersion, and adhesion dynamics will be developed. Such model will be used to predict particle delivery efficacy in idealized vascular networks and vasculatures reconstructed from scanned images. A fully integrated multiscale model, linking different functional biological scales, imaging and physical system, will allow system level nanomedicine evaluation for the first time.

The proposed multiscale simulation based method will provide a rigorous mathematical model of nanoparticle adhesion dynamics under complex vascular environment. Results of this work will pave the way toward new nanomedicine design and dosage choice guidances for targeted drug delivery. The proposed interdisciplinary research compliments the PI's educational goals by integrating research into educational and outreach activities such as graduate and undergraduate courses and engineering summer camps. An interactive website hosting graduate student's research projects will be created to allow high-school students to learn bio-nanotechnology online. The education plan will increase the awareness among high school teachers and students of the potential biomedical applications of nanotechnology, to advance understanding of nano-bio interfacial phenomena for students at all levels, and to increase minority participation in science and engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the major challenges of using nanoparticles (NP) in nanomedicine applications such as diagnostic imaging and targeted therapeutic applications is improving particle selectivity and adhesion efficiency under complex vascular flow conditions. The goal of this career development project is to develop an efficient multiscale modeling approach to help predict particle delivery process in blood flow.

First, we have developed an efficient and powerful computational platform to evaluate NP delivery in microcirculation together with red blood cells (RBC). By coupling Lattice Boltzmann and spring connected network models through immersed boundary method, we visualized the unique behavior of soft RBC under tank treading and tumbling motion. We benchmarked our computational model with a standard sphere dropping test. Then, by modeling nanoparticles motion using Langevin dynamics, we simulated the migration of particles mixed with cells under shear. We also showed that particle dispersion rate in RBC suspension is much larger than thermal diffusion rate. To characterize the NP migration speed, a modified dimensionless dispersion rate was introduced and formulated in terms of hematocrit and shear rates. To get a better qualitative understanding of in vivo transport process, we studied adhesion dynamic of drug carriers in microcirculation. In our particulate numerical study, attachment and detachment rates are replaced with adhesion probability function. We explored extensively the correlation between binding probability and actual deposition rate as well as the effect of other physical parameters such as shear rate, particle size and anti-ICAM1 density on particle binding.

Second, to predict the NP delivery in large scale, a human lung vascular 3-D model was constructed based on MRI data. As a first step toward modeling NP delivery in complex vasculature, we performed computational fluid-particle dynamic (CFPD) simulations in a typical portion of the lung vasculature consisting of four generations under steady and pulsatile flow. Ten million particles with diameters ranging from 1nm to 3µm are released into the original geometry. We found that NPs binding density in bifurcation regions is much higher than that in straight vessels under a pulsatile flow. It is also shown that for smaller particles, binding percentage is significantly higher when particles are released in pulsatile flow stream because the fluid mixing can be considerably enhanced by unsteady flows. In the next step, the whole pulmonary arterial tree is modeled by one representative pathway which is reconstructed by stitching truncated realistic and proposed artificial geometries. We were able to simulate the whole lung arterial network by one sample pathway. After benchmarking our truncated model, the pressure distribution of whole pulmonary vasculature was compared with results of lumped model. We have shown that flow rate and pressure distribution data of our truncated model matches well with the lumped model.

Overall, the computational method developed in this project is applicable to drug delivery in other organs and potentially could help build a whole body pharmacokinetic model for nanoparticle targeted delivery.  Besides scientific research, this project has provided training opportunities for multiple graduate, undergraduate, and high school students.  


Last Modified: 09/24/2016
Modified by: Yaling Liu

    Yaling Liu, Lehigh University
    Copyrighted
    Yaling Liu
    Modeling nanoparticle delivery in a vasculature
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: One of the major challenges of using nanoparticles (NP) in nanomedicine applications such as diagnostic imaging and targeted therapeutic applications is improving particle selectivity and adhesion efficiency under complex vascular flow conditions. The goal of this career development project is to develop an efficient multiscale modeling approach to help predict particle delivery process in blood flow. First, we have developed an efficient and powerful computational platform to evaluate NP delivery in microcirculation together with red blood cells (RBC). By coupling Lattice Boltzmann and spring connected network models through immersed boundary method, we visualized the unique behavior of soft RBC under tank treading and tumbling motion. We benchmarked our computational model with a standard sphere dropping test. Then, by modeling nanoparticles motion using Langevin dynamics, we simulated the migration of particles mixed with cells under shear. We also showed that particle dispersion rate in RBC suspension is much larger than thermal diffusion rate. To characterize the NP migration speed, a modified dimensionless dispersion rate was introduced and formulated in terms of hematocrit and shear rates. To get a better qualitative understanding of in vivo transport process, we studied adhesion dynamic of drug carriers in microcirculation. In our particulate numerical study, attachment and detachment rates are replaced with adhesion probability function. We explored extensively the correlation between binding probability and actual deposition rate as well as the effect of other physical parameters such as shear rate, particle size and anti-ICAM1 density on particle binding. Second, to predict the NP delivery in large scale, a human lung vascular 3-D model was constructed based on MRI data. As a first step toward modeling NP delivery in complex vasculature, we performed computational fluid-particle dynamic (CFPD) simulations in a typical portion of the lung vasculature consisting of four generations under steady and pulsatile flow. Ten million particles with diameters ranging from 1nm to 3µm are released into the original geometry. We found that NPs binding density in bifurcation regions is much higher than that in straight vessels under a pulsatile flow. It is also shown that for smaller particles, binding percentage is significantly higher when particles are released in pulsatile flow stream because the fluid mixing can be considerably enhanced by unsteady flows. In the next step, the whole pulmonary arterial tree is modeled by one representative pathway which is reconstructed by stitching truncated realistic and proposed artificial geometries. We were able to simulate the whole lung arterial network by one sample pathway. After benchmarking our truncated model, the pressure distribution of whole pulmonary vasculature was compared with results of lumped model. We have shown that flow rate and pressure distribution data of our truncated model matches well with the lumped model. Overall, the computational method developed in this project is applicable to drug delivery in other organs and potentially could help build a whole body pharmacokinetic model for nanoparticle targeted delivery. Besides scientific research, this project has provided training opportunities for multiple graduate, undergraduate, and high school students. Last Modified: 09/24/2016 Submitted by: Yaling Liu
